csv2db.py - upload table to database¶

Author:Andreas Heger
Release:$Id$
Date:April 02, 2014
Tags:Python

Purpose¶

create a table from a csv separated file and load data into it.

This module supports backends for postgres and sqlite3. Column types are auto-detected.

Read a table from stdin and create an sqlite3 database. By default, the database will reside in a file called csvdb and in a table csv.

Todo

Use file import where appropriate to speed up loading. Currently, this is not always the case.

Usage¶

Example:

python csv2db.py -b sqlite < stdin

Type:

python csv2db.py --help

for command line help.

Command line options¶

Usage: csv2db.py [options]

Options:
  --version             show program's version number and exit
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --no-usage            output help without usage information
  --dialect=DIALECT     csv dialect to use [default=excel-tab].
  -m MAP, --map=MAP     explicit mapping function for columns The format is
                        column:type (e.g.: length:int) [default=[]].
  -t TABLENAME, --table=TABLENAME
                        table name for all backends [default=csv].
  -d DATABASE, --database=DATABASE
                        database name for sqlite3 [default=csvdb].
  -H HEADER, --header=HEADER
                        ',' separated list of header for files without header
                        [default=none].
  --replace-header      replace header with --header instead of adding it
                        [default=False].
  -l, --lowercase       force lower case column names [default=False].
  -u, --ignore-duplicates
                        ignore columns with duplicate names [default=False].
  -s, --ignore-same     ignore columns with identical values [default=none].
  --ignore-column=IGNORE_COLUMNS
                        ignore columns [default=[]].
  --rename-column=RENAME_COLUMNS
                        rename columns [default=[]].
  --first-column=FIRST_COLUMN
                        name of first column - permits loading CSV table where
                        the first column name is the empty string
                        [default=none].
  -e, --ignore-empty    ignore columns which are all empty [default=False].
  -q, --quick           try quick file based import - needs to be supported by
                        the backend [default=False].
  -b BACKEND, --backend=BACKEND
                        database backend to choose [default=sqlite].
  -i INDICES, --index=INDICES
                        create an index for the named column [default=[]].
  -a, --allow-empty     allow empty table [default=False].
  --retry               retry if an SQL statement fails - warning: THIS MIGHT
                        CAUSE DEADLOCKS [default=False].
  -z, --from-zipped     input is zipped.
  --utf8                standard in is encoded as UTF8 rather than local
                        default, WARNING: does not strip comment lines yet
                        [default=none]
  -v LOGLEVEL, --verbose=LOGLEVEL
                        loglevel [1]. The higher, the more output.
  --timeit=TIMEIT_FILE  store timeing information in file [none].
  --timeit-name=TIMEIT_NAME
                        name in timing file for this class of jobs [all].
  --timeit-header       add header for timing information [none].
  --random-seed=RANDOM_SEED
                        random seed to initialize number generator with
                        [none].
  -C PSQL_CONNECTION, --connection=PSQL_CONNECTION
                        psql connection string [fgu202:postgres].
  -U USER, --user=USER  database user name [].
  -I FILE, --stdin=FILE
                        file to read stdin from [default = stdin].
  -L FILE, --log=FILE   file with logging information [default = stdout].
  -E FILE, --error=FILE
                        file with error information [default = stderr].
  -S FILE, --stdout=FILE
                        file where output is to go [default = stdout].
